item.title: The Future of Modern Warfare Is Being Built in Ukraine
item.description: After more than three years of all-out war with Russia, the country has turned into a factory of weaponry that’s redefining the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Alan Crawford, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: The preparation for the test ride of the ground robots TerMIT modular-tracked platforms used for logistic and distant mining the area.

item.title: Study Warns Trump’s Plan for US Aid Cuts Risks 14 Million Additional Deaths
item.description: Deep cuts to the US Agency for International Development and its potential dismantling under President Donald Trump could result in about 14 million additional deaths by 2030, according to a study released in a prominent medical journal.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: A demonstrattion in support of USAID workers in Washington, DC, in February.

item.title: China’s Private Factory Gauge Rebounds After US Trade Truce
item.description: China’s manufacturing activity rebounded in June, according to a private survey, suggesting relief after a trade-war truce with the US.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Yujing Liu

item.title: Trump Blasts Japan on Rice, Hassett Flags Looming Trade Deals
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened to proceed with ramping up tariffs on Japan, while his top economic adviser said the White House aims to finalize deals with partners after the July 4 holiday.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: A farmer harvests rice in a field in Tambasasayama, Japan.

item.title: China Sanctions Former Philippine Senator as Tensions Swell
item.description: China has sanctioned former Philippine Senator Francis Tolentino, prohibiting him from entering mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, in a rare move as tensions with Manila rise.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Red flags outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai PM Revamps Cabinet in Bid to Steady Wobbly Government
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra revamped her cabinet, a move aimed at easing a political crisis that brought her government to the brink over her handling of a border dispute.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Solar, Wind Industries See Existential Threat in Senate Tax Bill
item.description: A proposed excise tax would exacerbate the pain from the phaseout of subsidies.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Ma

media:content.media:description: Solar panels at the Cascadilla Community Solar Farm, owned by Cornell University, in Dryden, New York, US, on Monday, April 10, 2023. US college costs just keep climbing and the increase is pushing the annual price for the upcoming academic year at Ivy League schools toward yet another hold-on-to-your-mortarboard mark.

item.title: Harvard-White House Talks Stall, Threatening Quick Settlement
item.description: Harvard University’s talks with the White House have stalled, according to a person familiar with the matter, threatening a quick resolution to a standoff that’s endangering the school’s finances and upending foreign student plans.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: The Lowell House on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Senate Heads Into All-Nighter on Trump Tax Bill With GOP Divided
item.description: Senate Republican leaders continue to scrounge for votes to pass Donald Trump’s $3.3 trillion tax and spending bill as lingering intraparty fights threaten to upend the legislative centerpiece of the president’s domestic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Joni Ernst Photographer: Allison Robbert/Bloomberg

item.title: NYC Passes $116 Billion Budget With Boost to Migrant Legal Aid
item.description: New York City Mayor Eric Adams reached a deal with the City Council on a $115.9 billion budget, adding new funding for legal services for migrants and more money for early childhood education.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Eric Adams (center) is running for reelection as an independent.

item.title: Senate Republicans Seek to Ease Solar and Wind Tax Credit Cutoff
item.description: A group of Senate Republicans is pushing a plan to soften an aggressive planned phase out of subsidies for wind and solar projects under President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending package.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Senator Joni Ernst

item.title: US Plans to Boost Soy Exports to Italy and Form New Task Force
item.description: Italy will increase its imports of US soybeans as part of a new effort to rebalance trade between the two countries, US Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins told reporters Monday after meeting with her Italian counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Peterson

media:content.media:description: Soybeans ready for planting at Double G Angus Farms in Tiffin, Iowa, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Soybean futures posted the biggest intraday gain in more than three weeks on Wednesday after the US and China confirmed trade talks, lifting market sentiment over demand for American crop supplies.

item.title: What Are the Digital Services Taxes Drawing Trump’s Ire?
item.description: Digital services taxes targeting the revenue of big technology companies have returned as a flash point in President Donald Trump’s efforts to rewrite the rules of global trade.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: The Microsoft Teams app on a laptop

item.title: Netanyahu Is Set to Meet Trump at White House on July 7
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House on July 7, according to Israeli and US officials, as the administration urges its ally to end the war in Gaza and secure the release of the remaining hostages held by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, left, and Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's prime minister, during an arrival ceremony outside the West Wing of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, April 7, 2025. Netanyahu is meeting with Trump to seek a better tariff deal for Israel and to discuss the war in Gaza, the situation in Syria and the Iranian nuclear program.

item.title: A Trio of US Treasury Hacks Exposes a Pattern Making Banks Nervous
item.description: In three major hacks, Treasury didn’t deploy cybersecurity measures that could have prevented the attacks or flagged the intruders sooner, a Bloomberg News investigation found.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Robertson, Hannah Levitt, Jake Bleiberg, Jason Leopold

item.title: Thai Political Crisis Deepens as Shinawatras Face Legal Battles
item.description: Thailand’s most influential political dynasty is facing two high-profile legal battles, with an unfavorable outcome for Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra likely to deepen a political crisis that’s already pushed her government to the brink of collapse.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk Lashes Out at Tax Bill Proponents, Threatens to Unseat Lawmakers
item.description: Elon Musk once again threatened to ramp up his political spending, this time targeting nearly every sitting Republican in Congress who has signaled support for President Donald Trump’s multi-trillion dollar tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Sapienza

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a cabinet meeting at the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. US President Donald Trump said he is looking to allow undocumented farm and hospitality industry workers to leave the US for a short period of time and reenter the country legally, a bid to address concerns about labor shortages from his crackdown on undocumented migration.

item.title: Trump Lifts Syria Sanctions in Bid to Boost New Government
item.description: President Donald Trump signed an executive order terminating US sanctions on Syria, aiming to boost the nation’s struggling economy and support the new government after rebels overthrew President Bashar Al-Assad last year.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: People celebrate in Damascus' Omeyyad square after US President Donald Trump's decision to lift sanctions in Syria, on May 13.

item.title: Judge Seeks US Assurances on Deportations in Birthright Case
item.description: A judge overseeing a challenge to President Donald Trump’s restrictions on automatic birthright citizenship asked the US government to confirm it won’t seek to deport impacted children during the Supreme Court’s 30-day pause on enforcement of the directive.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 20, 2025. Trump signaled he would give diplomacy a chance before deciding whether to strike Iran, dialing back on recent comments that suggested military action could be imminent.

item.title: EU to Accept Trump Universal Tariff But Seeks Key Exemptions
item.description: The European Union is willing to accept a trade arrangement with the US that includes a 10% universal tariff on many of the bloc’s exports, but wants the US to commit to lower rates on key sectors such as pharmaceuticals, alcohol, semiconductors and commercial aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Richest 20% Get an Average $6,055 Income Boost in Trump Tax Bill
item.description: The Senate’s version of President Donald Trump’s proposed tax cut bill will cost the bottom 20% of taxpayers an average of $560 a year while giving an average boost of $6,055 to those at the top end.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol during high temperatures in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 23, 2025. Electricity use on the biggest US grid, which serves nearly a fifth of Americans from Washington DC to Illinois, is expected to climb to a 12-year high as intense heat spurs air conditioning needs.

item.title: Trump’s TikTok Buyer Is the Same Group Behind a Previous Stalled Bid
item.description: The prospective buyer of TikTok’s American operations cited by President Donald Trump is the same investor consortium including Oracle Corp., Blackstone Inc. and venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, whose bid for the app had stalled amid US-China trade tensions, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference in the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. Trump says the US has made a trade deal with "probably four or five different countries," naming agreements with China and the UK.

item.title: Trump, Republicans Rush to Overcome Internal Clashes on Tax Bill
item.description: Republican Party leaders are rushing to overcome lingering internal fights over President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending package as Democrats launch attacks to exploit the divisions.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Jamie Tarabay, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Starmer’s Welfare Overhaul Hangs in Balance Ahead of Key Vote
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is girding for what could be the most consequential vote of his premiership, with Labour rebels warning that the government’s welfare overhaul still risks defeat despite huge concessions to push it through parliament.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer

item.title: Chile Peso Gains as Communist Win Is Seen as a Step Too Far for Left
item.description: Chile’s peso jumped on Monday as a landslide victory for Communist Jeannette Jara in a left-wing presidential primary damped the chances of that alliance winning November’s election.
item.dc:creator: Philip Sanders

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara at a presidential primary election night rally in Santiago on June 29. Photographer: Cristobal Olivares/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Lawsuit Claims Los Angeles’ Sanctuary Policy Fueled Riots
item.description: The Trump administration sued Los Angeles claiming its sanctuary city ordinance helped fuel riots during protests against the president’s deportation crackdown, prompting the US to send in national guard troops.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: Police fire less lethal projectiles during clashes between protesters and law enforcement in Los Angeles.

item.title: Italy to Allow 500,000 New Migrant Entries in Next Three Years
item.description: Italy’s cabinet approved a decree that lets almost 500,000 documented immigrants enter the country in the next three years.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Sonia Sirletti

media:content.media:description: Italy's prime minister Giorgia Meloni

item.title: Hungary’s Orban Moves to Downplay Pride Parade Protest
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban sought to play down a backlash against his rule at Hungary’s weekend Pride parade, portraying it as a “shameful” event orchestrated by the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik, Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: Budapest Pride participants cross Elisabeth Bridge on June 28.

item.title: SNAP Cuts in Big Tax Bill Will Hit a Lot of Trump Voters Too
item.description: More than 40 million people relied on the food-assistance program in 2024, or about 12% of the population. Many are located in red districts represented by legislators who support gutting the aid.
item.dc:creator: Deena Shanker

item.title: Netherlands Delays Decision on TenneT’s German Grid Deal
item.description: The Dutch government needs more time to assess the options for TenneT Holding BV’s German high-voltage business and a decision is likely to come in September.
item.dc:creator: Eyk Henning

media:content.media:description: Cables hang from electricity pylons at the BritNed interconnector, a new 1-gigawatt electricity link between Britain and the Netherlands, operated as a joint venture between National Grid Plc and TenneT Holding BV, near Rochester, U.K., on Thursday, March 24, 2016. A U.K. vote to leave the European Union might force gas and power bills up by 500 million pounds ($700 million) a year, Rudd said on Thursday, warning that a "Brexit" would threaten Britain's energy security.
